author: S Poorvaja
text:
Despite having performed a number of times in Chennai before, the concert on Saturday evening for Shankar, Ehsaan and Loy was a special one.

“As musicians, we sometimes do have to go beyond the entertainment factor and are happy to perform for a cause,” said Shankar Mahadevan. The trio performed in the city on Saturday for ‘Gurukripa 2016,’ a fundraising concert for The Shakti Foundation.

The musicians said that the cause they were performing for — towards an inclusive society for people with disabilities and creating barrier-free public spaces — was something that was close to their heart. “In many other countries, barrier-free public spaces are just taken for granted because all the facilities needed for access such as ramps and pathways are already in place. Even if not shops, malls and theatres, we need to start from footpaths and pavements on the roads here for easy access,” said Ehsaan Noorani.

Stating that the country was marching towards progress and change, Loy Medonsa said that more action was, however, needed for implementing measures for an inclusive environment.

Having performed for The Shakti Foundation before, the trio said that it had always been a fantastic experience to perform for children and see them smile.

“There are so many stories of differently-abled children and adults having made it big. We want to ensure that more such successes are possible for many out there, which can be facilitated through a barrier-free environment and an inclusive community,” said Vasanth Raghuvir, founder of The Shakti Foundation.

title: Music trio voice support for an inclusive society
